FacilityName: Walter M. Higgins III Generating Station
ParentCompanyName: Nevada Power Company d/b/a NV Energy

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
lic.

Summary of the Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases from the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at the facility in the past five years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Summary of the Emergency Response Program

The emergency action plan for the facility has been reviewed with outside emergency response agencies, including the Clark County Fire Department and local emergency planning committee (LEPC).  Mock drills of ammonia releases have been conducted with off-site emergency responders.  

The following core elements comprise the Emergency Response Program at Plant Higgins: 

1) Assignment of level of authority and associated responsibilities for facility personnel during an accidental release of ammonia; 2) Training requirements for facility personnel; 3) Medical treatment facilities; 4) Notification procedures for critical NVE personnel and outside responding agencies, including, but not limited to local and public agencies, the Clark County Fire Department, the Nevada Office of Emergency Management and the National Response Center (as necessary); 5)  Instructions to mitigate or eliminate the release; 6) Evacuation and Shelter-in-Place techniques and 7) Access to Material Safety Data Sheets.

Nevada Power Company d/b/a NV Energy owns and operates the Walter M. Higgins III Generating Station (Higgins), a nominal 580-megawatt power plant located in Primm, Nevada. Higgins uses aqueous ammonia solution (29 percent by weight) in the selective catalytic reduction process for controlling the nitrogen oxides emissions.

The scope of this RMP is based on the 40 CFR Part 68 and other published guidelines by U.S.EPA.  The aqueous ammonia storage and handling system is the only process at Higgins that triggers the RMP requirements. This process was determined to be covered by federal RMP Program Level 1 requirements.

The aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at the facility is comprised of a single storage tank, pumps, and piping which terminate at the vaporizer where the aqueous ammonia is atomized to concentrations below 20 percent. The tank is 33,500 gallons in volume and is equipped with pressure relief valves, temperature, pressure, and level indicators. The facility has an administrative storage limit of 85% of the maximum storage capacity.  The tank is also surrounded by an enclosure for containing the entire contents of the storage tank in case of equipment failure.

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

The offsite consequence analysis was conducted using the EPA's RMP Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (March 2009). The worst-case release scenario was developed assuming that the entire contents of the aqueous ammonia storage tank are released through a failed tank or pipe into the secondary containment dike that is large enough to contain the entire volume. Under worst-case meteorological conditions, 1.5 m/s wind speed and a stable (Pasquill F) atmospheric stability class, and assuming a release rate that accounts for a temperature correction factor of the highest recorded daily temperature in a preceding 3 year period, the ammonia cloud could travel 0.2 miles before dispersing sufficiently to no longer pose a health hazard to the pub
